'''Duff Beer''' is a brand of [[beer]] that originated as a [[List of fictional brewers|fictional beverage]] on the [[List of animated television series|animated series]] ''[[The Simpsons]]''. Beers using the Duff branding have been brewed in a number of countries, resulting in legal battles with varying results. An official version of the beer is sold in three variations near [[the Simpsons Ride]] at [[Universal Studios Theme Parks|Universal Studios]]. In 2015, [[21st Century Fox]], producer of ''The Simpsons'', began selling licensed Duff beer in Chile, with a view to driving out [[brandjacking]].<ref name="Hagey2015">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/duff-beer-tries-to-tap-markets-outside-springfield-1436553842|title=‘The Simpsons’ Duff Beer Tries to Tap Markets Outside Springfield|last=Hagey|first=Keach|date=July 10, 2015|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Lince2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtrademarkreview.com/Blog/detail.aspx?g=5ca56ceb-9e36-443d-b5fc-0645a6b725b6|title=Duff Beer launches in response to counterfeits but challenges in Europe remain|last=Lince|first=Tim|date=July 17, 2015|work=[[World Trademark Review]]|publisher=Globe Business Media Group|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
In 2016, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' included Duff Beer in a list of the most influential fictional companies of all time.<ref name="infl comp">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4351022/influential-fake-companies/?xid=homepage|title=The 18 Most Influential Fake Companies of All Time|accessdate=June 7, 2016|date=June 2, 2016|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602175058/http://time.com/4351022/influential-fake-companies/?xid=homepage|archivedate=June 2, 2016|first1=Alex|last1=Fitzpatrick|first2=Matt|last2=Vella|first3=Lisa|last3=Eadicicco|first4=Matt|last4=Peckham|first5=John Patrick|last5=Pullen|first6=Sarah|last6=Begley|first7=Daniel|last7=D'Addario}}</ref>
==Duff in ''The Simpsons''== Duff is [[Homer Simpson]]'s beer of choice. It is a parody of stereotypical mass-market [[American lager]]: cheap, poor-quality, and heavily marketed.
The beer's slogan is "Can't Get Enough of That Wonderful Duff", though there are others. In "[[Duffless]]", parking lot signs at the Duff brewery have the slogans "It's Always Time For Duff" and "Now Leaving Duff Country". In "[[Homer's Odyssey (The Simpsons)|Homer's Odyssey]]", Duff is described as "The beer that makes the days fly by".
Their spokesperson is [[List of recurring The Simpsons characters#Duffman|Duffman]], a parody of [[Budweiser]]'s '70s-era mascot [[Bud Man]]. He is a muscular, bleach-blond, well-tanned man with whitened teeth who wears a blue leotard and cape, red Duff Beer ballcap, mirror sunglasses, and a utility belt full of cans of Duff Beer. He speaks in a loud and overly-enthusiastic staccato voice (like a radio DJ or beer commercial pitchman) and does a lot of exaggerated physical movements like a male exotic dancer - like dancing in place, groin-thrusting, hip shaking, and rubbing his buttocks with a towel. There are apparently many identical Duffmen; however, like mall Santas they never appear at the same place at the same time (to not disillusion the kids). One retired Duffman in [[Alcoholics Anonymous]] referred to himself as "Barry Duffman", indicating that he had to assume the identity of Duffman as part of the job. Some of the actors who play him have actually died (presumably from alcohol-related causes); their demise was never acknowledged because the character of Duffman is unaging and immortal. At public appearances he is often flanked by a random pair of beautiful, scantily-clad women who act as arm-candy, backup dancers, and assistants.
While Duff Beer comes in several varieties, it is revealed on a Duff Brewery tour in "[[Duffless]]" that regular Duff, Duff Light, and Duff Dry are the same beer, although Homer and [[Barney Gumble|Barney]] apparently remain oblivious to the fact. A tasting room contains Duff Dark beer and Duff Gummy Beers candy; it also contains several varieties that Barney stated they had not tried yet: Raspberry Duff, Lady Duff and Tartar Control Duff.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Duffless |series=The Simpsons |season=4 |number=16}}</ref>
In "[[A Tree Grows in Springfield]]", Homer asks for [[Moe Szyslak|Moe]]'s best beer, so Moe gives him a Duff Adequate.<ref>{{cite episode |title=A Tree Grows in Springfield |series=The Simpsons |season=24 |number=6}}</ref> In "[[The Great Louse Detective]]", Duffman claims that Duff Stout is "the beer that made [[Ireland]] famous".<ref>{{cite episode |title=The Great Louse Detective |series=The Simpsons |season=14 |number=6}}</ref>
In "[[Homer the Moe]]", Moe sells "Malaysian Duff", which is made with [[soy sauce]] at his trendy bar. In "[[The Springfield Files]]", Homer is craving something different than the usual Duff. So Moe gives Homer a bottle of "Düff" (Swedish Duff) - it's just a can of regular Duff with the [[Diaeresis (diacritic)|accent mark]] drawn on in marker pen.
In "[[The War of Art (The Simpsons)|The War of Art]]", Homer offers [[Kirk Van Houten]] a bottle of Canadian Duff (or ''Le Duff avec [[Codeine]]'' on the label in French), which is laced with [[Cough Medicine]].<ref>{{cite episode |title=The War of Art |series=The Simpsons |season=25 |number=15}}</ref> The label on the bottle's neck has a picture of Canadian [[Duffman]] wearing a [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police|Mountie]] uniform and saying his catch phrase in both English (''Oh Yeah!'') and French (''Mais Oui!'').
In "[[Burns Verkaufen der Kraftwerk]]", Homer celebrates a recent minor stock windfall by ordering a bottle of Henry K. Duff's Private Reserve, which is implied to be more costly and of better quality, and which is an apparent spoof of [[Henry Weinhard's|Henry Weinhard's Private Reserve]]. <ref>{{cite episode |title=Burns Verkaufen der Kraftwerk |series=The Simpsons |season=3 |number=11}}</ref>
In the season 21 episode "[[To Surveil With Love]]", Duffman makes a giveaway of Duff advertising in Moe's bar while "[[Get Ready For This]]" by [[2 Unlimited]] plays on the background, suggesting this might be the theme song for the beer brand or for the character.
Fudd, a competitor to Duff, appears in the episodes "[[Colonel Homer]]" and "[[Lemon of Troy]]", the latter showing it being enjoyed by residents of [[Springfield (The Simpsons)#Shelbyville|Shelbyville]], rival town to the Simpsons' home of [[Springfield (The Simpsons)|Springfield]]. Consumption of Fudd however is alleged by bartender Moe Szyslak to have made hillbillies go blind.
===Duff Gardens=== In the episode entitled "[[Selma's Choice]]", [[Bart Simpson|Bart]] and [[Lisa Simpson]] travel with their aunt [[Patty and Selma Bouvier|Selma]] to Duff Gardens, a parody of the [[Busch Gardens]] amusement park, but also containing elements of [[Disneyland Park (Anaheim)|Disneyland]]. In the gift shop, Bart spots "[[Alcohol and sex#"Beer goggles"|beer goggles]]", spectacles that mimic what drunks see: they make Aunt Selma appear young, feminine, and beautiful to Bart - and also, somehow, alter her voice. Later, they see the [[mascot]]s of Duff Beer, the Seven Duffs.
In the same episode, there is also a direct [[parody]] of the "[[It's a Small World]]" attraction at [[Walt Disney Parks and Resorts|Disney parks]]. In the cartoon, the boats float on a brown liquid as [[Audio-Animatronics|animatronic]] children sing ''"Duff beer for me, Duff beer for you, I'll have a Duff, You have one, too,"'' over and over again. Lisa drinks the liquid in the ride on a dare from Bart, and she freaks out from its [[Psychedelics, dissociatives and deliriants|hallucinogenic]] properties.
Other Duff Gardens attractions include the [[beer can pyramid|Beeramid]], the Beerquarium ("Home of the world's happiest fish"), the Beer Hall of Presidents, the Washing Machine ride, the Whiplash rollercoaster, singing group Hooray for Everything (who sing a politically correct version of [[Lou Reed]]'s "[[Walk on the Wild Side (Lou Reed song)|Walk on the Wild Side]]" and are based on [[Up with People]]), and a direct parody of Disneyland's [[Main Street Electrical Parade]].
====The Seven Duffs==== The Seven Duffs are characters at the Duff Gardens [[amusement park|theme park]]. The "Duffs" are a reference to [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney]]'s ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]''. The Seven Duffs are named Sleazy, Queasy, Surly, Edgy, Tipsy, Dizzy, and Remorseful.
==Creation== Some have speculated that the name was inspired by one-syllable beer names in the [[United States]] (such as "[[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Bud]]"), and ''The Simpsons''' writers had found the name humorous.<ref name="Record"/> However, longtime Simpsons animator, producer, and director David Silverman has stated that Groening named the beer "Duff" simply for the convenient rhyme in the slogan "Can't Get Enough of that Wonderful Duff".<ref name="David Silverman">{{cite web | title = Tweet by David Silverman | url = https://twitter.com/tubatron/status/268158159842058240 | publisher = Twitter | date = November 12, 2012 | accessdate = December 12, 2012}}</ref>
In an excerpt from his autobiography, [[Guns N' Roses]] bassist [[Duff McKagan]] claimed that the beer was named after him as the writers were fans of the band and he was known for his extreme alcohol consumption and was popularly called "The King of Beers".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maxim.com/amg/MUSIC/Articles/GunsNRoses+Nearly+Killed+Duff+McKagan |title=GunsNRoses Nearly Killed Duff McKagan |accessdate=August 15, 2011}}</ref> This is a claim ''Simpsons'' creator Matt Groening has called "absurd".<ref name="Matt Groening">{{cite web | title = Tweet by Simpsons music editor Chris Ledesma | url = https://twitter.com/mxedtr/status/268989056149487616 | publisher = Twitter | date = November 15, 2012 | accessdate = December 12, 2012}}</ref> In response McKagan has stated that he thought it was common knowledge and uncontroversial that he was the origin of the name, and jokingly called assertions to the contrary "absurd."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Apw9vgTzZ_I#t=480 |title=Duff McKagan + Jeff Angell of Walking Papers - Wikipedia: Fact or Fiction? |accessdate=December 6, 2014}}</ref>
In fact, [[Moe's Tavern]] is a very close recreation of a tavern that was a block from the University of Oregon when Groening was there, called Duffy's.<ref>http://boundless.uoregon.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php? CISOROOT=/archpnw&CISOPTR=8650&CISOBOX=1&REC=8</ref> It even had red and green diamond pane windows inside.{{citation needed|date = February 2016}} The beer of choice was Blitz Weinhard, aka Blitz.{{citation needed|date = February 2016}}
==Real Duff beers== [[Matt Groening]] has stated that he will not license the Duff trademark to brew an actual beer, over concern that it would encourage children to drink.<ref name=sixpack>{{cite web|url=http://www.joesixpack.net/columnArchives/2007/072707.htm|title=Joe Sixpack - Reporting and drinking beer in Philly and beyond|author=|date=|website=www.joesixpack.net|accessdate=November 9, 2017}}</ref> However, there have been a few notable cases of individual companies and persons who have used the term "Duff Beer" with varying success.
===United States=== [[Duff's Famous Wings]] in [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] and [[Rochester, New York]] sells their own form of Duff's beer on tap.{{citation needed|date = February 2016}}
Bilbo's pizza and brewery in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]] also brewed their own form of Duff beer, which had a Homer Simpson tap handle to complete the reference.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foodspotting.com/places/518033-bilbo-s-pizza-in-a-pan-kalamazoo/best|title=Bilbo's Pizza In A Pan|website=www.foodspotting.com|language=en|access-date=January 27, 2017}}</ref>
On June 1, 2013, [[Universal Studios Florida]] began offering Duff Beer in their expanded Springfield area at a replica of Moe's Tavern and a waterfront Duff Brewery.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://floridabeerblog.wordpress.com/2014/10/05/brew-review-duff-beer-at-universal-orlando-universalorl-florida-beer-craftbeer/|title=Brew Review – Duff Beer at Universal Orlando|author=|date=October 5, 2014|website=wordpress.com|accessdate=November 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Germany=== [[File:AKE Duff Beer IMG 5244 edit.jpg|thumb|upright|right|"The Legendary Duff Beer", brewed in Germany for Duff Beer UG]] In [[Germany]] the Eschweger Klosterbrauerei, a brewery in [[Hessen]], brewed a Duff Beer under the German [[Reinheitsgebot]], under contract for Duff Beer UG.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6&Itemid=2|publisher=Duff Beer UG|language=German|title=Produkt|accessdate=November 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229072022/http://www.duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6&Itemid=2|archivedate=February 29, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_contact&view=contact&id=1&Itemid=27|title=Kontakt (haftungsbeschränkt)|publisher=Duff Beer UG|language=German|accessdate=November 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229071841/http://www.duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_contact&view=contact&id=1&Itemid=27|archivedate=February 29, 2012|df=}}</ref> It was distributed in many European countries,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86&Itemid=59|title=Partner Europa|publisher=Duff Beer UG|language=German|accessdate=November 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229071906/http://www.duff-bier.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=86&Itemid=59|archivedate=February 29, 2012|df=}}</ref> and in Australia from 2011.<ref name="Scardamaglia">{{cite web|url=http://fortnightlyreview.info/tag/eschweger-klosterbrauerei/|title=The Return of Duff Beer – Only This Time it’s 'Legendary' |last=Scardamaglia|first=Amanda|date=November 4, 2011|work=The Fortnightly Review of IP & Media Law|publisher=IPRIA and CMCL|accessdate=November 15, 2012|location=University of Melbourne}}</ref>
====European Trademark==== [[File:Duff beverage GmbH beer.jpg|thumb|A can of Duff Beer, manufactured by Duff Beverage GmbH]] Duff Beer UG applied for an EU [[Community Trade Mark]] (CTM) in 2009, which was opposed by Twentieth Century Fox.<ref>Community Trade Mark No. 008351091 on [http://oami.europa.eu/CTMOnline/RequestManager/en_SearchBasic CTM-ONLINE] at website of [[Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market]], accessed November 16, 2012</ref> In 2011 the [[Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market]] decided in favour of Fox, and in 2012 Duff Beer UG appealed to the [[European Court of Justice]] (ECJ).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://curia.europa.eu/juris/liste.jsf?language=en&num=T-87/12 |title=T-87/12 - Duff Beer v OHMI - Twentieth Century Fox Film (Duff) |work=[[Europa (web portal)|Europa]]|accessdate=November 17, 2012}}</ref>
Twentieth Century Fox had itself been granted a CTM for the logo "Duff BEER" for use in several categories of non-beer merchandise.<ref name="CTMFox">Community Trade Mark No. 001341130 on [http://oami.europa.eu/CTMOnline/RequestManager/en_SearchBasic CTM-ONLINE] at website of [[Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market]], accessed November 17, 2012</ref> Fox had applied for the CTM in 1999, but opposition from the makers of "Mac Duff's"-branded wine and spirits delayed the grant till 2006.<ref name="CTMFox"/> Fox's CTM was cancelled by the OHIM in 2011,<ref name="CTMFox"/> following a 2010 ruling by the Brussels Commercial Court that a "Beer" logo applied exclusively to non-beer merchandise was misleading.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.internationallawoffice.com/newsletters/detail.aspx?g=81c2530c-ba24-4363-835c-1bf7a941a170|title=Trademarks, virtual products and Homer Simpson's favourite beer|last=Vrins|first=Olivier|author2=Katia De Clercq|work=Intellectual Property - Belgium|publisher=International Law Office|accessdate=November 17, 2012}}</ref>
In 2014, Duff Beer UG's CTM was transferred to Fox, and the ECJ case was withdrawn.<ref name="Lince2015" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://register.dpma.de/DPMAregister/marke/register/3020080770708/DE?lang=en|title=Register number: 302008077070|work=DPMA register|publisher=DPMA|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&docid=151047&pageIndex=0&doclang=en&mode=req&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=712411|title=Order of the General Court — Duff Beer v OHIM — Twentieth Century Fox Film (Duff)|date=February 6, 2014|work=Curia|publisher=[[Europa (Web portal)|Europa]]|accessdate=September 8, 2016}}</ref> There was also a German trademark registered in 1999 to Duff Beverage GmbH, creating what one lawyer in 2015 called a "very complex situation".<ref name="Lince2015" />
===United Kingdom=== [[Daleside Brewery]] in [[England]] makes a beer called Duff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/daleside-duff/5502/|title=Daleside Duff|author=|date=|website=RateBeer|accessdate=November 9, 2017}}</ref> [[#Germany|Duff Beer UG's beer]] is distributed in the United Kingdom as "The Legendary Duff Beer".<ref name="duffbeerUK">{{cite web|url=http://www.duffbeer.co.uk/about-us/|title=About Us|work=The Legendary Duff Beer|publisher=Duff Beer Distribution|accessdate=November 15, 2012}}</ref> While news reports of its 2011 introduction mentioned ''The Simpsons'',<ref>{{cite web |first=Emma |last=Hutchings |date=February 22, 2012 |url=http://www.psfk.com/2012/02/homer-simpsons-duff-beer-uk.html |title=Homer Simpson’s Duff Beer Goes On Sale In The UK}}</ref> its own website does not, although it refers to its "iconic packaging" and states "The product has certainly fulfilled its namesake in becoming a modern day legend".<ref name="duffbeerUK"/>
===Australia=== [[File:Australian Duff beer can.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Can of the Lion Nathan-produced Duff beer]] In the mid 1990s, the [[Lion Nathan]] brewery in [[Australia]] produced a beer called Duff. [[20th Century Fox]] brought legal action against the company.<ref name="Record">{{cite news|title=Homer's creators sue Aussie brewery for selling Duff Beer |date=April 22, 1996|page=B7|publisher=[[Waterloo Region Record|The Record]]|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> The product was ordered to be pulled from store shelves and destroyed, because of the likely association in public mind between the ''Simpsons'' brand and characters and Lion Nathan's product, though the manufacturer did not use any ''Simpsons'' characters or the ''Simpsons'' Duff Beer design.<ref name="Scardamaglia"/> The beer became a collectors' item in the process, with one case selling for [[United States dollar|US$]]13,000.<ref name=sip>{{cite news|title=Sip Homer's brew |date=January 3, 1999|page=036|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Michael|last=Idato}}</ref>
[[#Germany|Duff Beer UG's beer]] was introduced in Australia in 2011.<ref name="Scardamaglia"/>
On September 8, 2014 another incarnation of Duff which had only been launched in May 2014<ref>http://www.theage.com.au/business/retail/duff-dumped-woolworths-simpsons-beer-ruled-highly-appealing-to-children-20140911-10fet9.html</ref> for sale through the Woolworths chain was pulled from Australian shelves due to a complaint to Alcohol Beverages Advertising Code adjudication panel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoppsy.com/australia/wont-somebody-please-think-of-the-children-duff-banned-down-under/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 8, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908180512/http://www.hoppsy.com/australia/wont-somebody-please-think-of-the-children-duff-banned-down-under/ |archivedate=September 8, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===Chile=== The [[Investigations Police of Chile]] seized 60,000 bottles of Duff-brand beer in the city of Linares following an intellectual property complaint from 20th Century Fox in March 2013.<ref>[http://www.latercera.com/noticia/nacional/2013/03/680-515655-9-20th-century-fox-pide-incautacion-de-cerveza-chilena.shtml/ 20th Century Fox pide incautación de cerveza chilena (in Spanish)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326181720/http://www.latercera.com/noticia/nacional/2013/03/680-515655-9-20th-century-fox-pide-incautacion-de-cerveza-chilena.shtml/ |date=March 26, 2013 }}</ref>
Partially due to unauthorized Duff beer in the country, Fox announced plans to sell official Duff beer in Chile starting in early 2016, with plans to expand elsewhere in South America and into Europe. Producing a real Duff beer will allow Fox stronger [[trademark]] protections of the Duff name; as a fictional product, it is more susceptible to piracy.<ref name="Hagey2015"/>
===Mexico=== Since 2006, Rodrigo Contreras, from [[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]], [[Mexico]] is setting up a business with the purpose of selling Duff beer. He managed to register the "Duff" trademark in Mexico, as well as the domain name DuffDeMexico.com. Contreras designed the bottle to be identical to the one portrayed on ''The Simpsons''. The bottle can be seen at his website. The beer is currently available at a few bars, but Contreras has stated his intention of selling it at convenience stores and even exporting it to the United States.<ref>[http://www.mundocerveza.com/2007/07/23/mmmh-cerveeeezaa/ Mmmh… Cerveeeezaa…!] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206052732/http://www.mundocerveza.com/2007/07/23/mmmh-cerveeeezaa/ |date=December 6, 2007 }} MundoCerveza.com (in Spanish)</ref>
This case has been featured on several Mexican newspapers and magazines, but most of them focus on the novelty the beer represents, rather than the legal implications of it. The "Duff" trademark was not registered in Mexico before Contreras registered it; however, Mexican [[intellectual property]] [[law]] recognizes the concept of "brand notoriety", which states that if any brand is well known by a specific section of the consumers or the industry due to the commercial activities or advertisement done by its owners, they have the right to claim the ownership of the trademark.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.buyusa.gov/mexico/en/403.pdf |title=Current Issues of Mexican Intellectual Property |accessdate=December 23, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324114935/https://www.buyusa.gov/mexico/en/403.pdf |archivedate=March 24, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Since its inception, the Mexican brand Duff has spread to other countries in Latin-America like Brazil,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.duffbrasil.com.br/ |title=Duff Brazil Website |accessdate=December 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214075201/http://www.duffbrasil.com.br/ |archivedate=December 14, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Chile, Colombia, among others.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.duffsudamerica.com/inicio.html |title=Duff South America |accessdate=December 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106055612/http://www.duffsudamerica.com/inicio.html |archivedate=November 6, 2012 |df= }}</ref> In some countries, the legal implications and intellectual property is being questioned by Fox representatives, but no court decision has been met yet.{{citation needed|date = February 2016}}
===France=== [[#Germany|Duff Beer UG's beer]] was introduced into France in 2011, though with limited success.<ref name="ouestfrance"/> Since French television has a strict prohibition on [[Alcohol advertising|advertising and product placement of alcohol]], subsequent broadcasts of ''The Simpsons'' have blurred the Duff logo on screen.<ref name="ouestfrance"/> The name is not censored on the soundtrack, but [[Duffman]] was redubbed "Uffman".<ref name="ouestfrance">{{cite news|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuDet_-W9-censure-la-Duff-la-biere-d-Homer-Simpson_39382-2114148_actu.Htm|title=W9 censure la Duff, la bière d’Homer Simpson|date=September 18, 2012|work=[[Ouest-France]]|language=French|accessdate=November 15, 2012}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== Duff Brewery in [[Dunedin]], [[New Zealand]] brewed Duff Beer many years before ''The Simpsons'', but due to threatened legal action by [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] they negotiated at name to McDuff.[https://www.odt.co.nz/business/mcduffs-calls-‘last-drinks’]
===Duff Energy Drink=== [[File:Duff Energy Drink (close-up).JPG|thumb|right|130px|Duff Energy Drink]] The gift shop of [[The Simpsons Ride]] at [[Universal Studios Theme Parks|Universal Studios]] sells a canned [[energy drink]] made by Boston America Corp. that is designed to look like a Duff Beer can. It is also sold at a limited number of other locations, including [[Five Below]], [[2nd & Charles]],<ref name=sip/> and in the UK at American import stores such as Cybercandy, and Bootleggers.

'''Ethics and religious culture''' ('''Éthique et culture religieuse''') is a course taught in all elementary and high schools in [[Quebec]]. It replaces the abolished subject of religious/moral education in these schools and is compulsory in all schools: private as well as public. The aim of the subject is to develop ethical thinking and dialog skills in response to the changing religious/ non religious diversity of cultural communities in the Province. It also allows for all students to understand Quebec's religious history. ( MELS ERC Curriculum LEARN QUEBEC) The program's twin paramount principles are Recognition of Others and Pursuit of the Common Good. It is also claimed that the course will promote a "culture of dialogue" among students.
The project was adopted under the liberal government of [[Jean Charest]], and has garnered some controversy. The first year this course has been taught is 2008-2009.
== Controversy ==
The course has been opposed by three main groups:
# Secularists from the Mouvement laïque québécois because they believe that ethics and religious culture should not be taught within a single course ; also, they believe that teaching both of these subjects together induce people to think that it is not possible to behave ethically without any religious belief ; # French nationalists who accuse the program to be a kind of ''Multiculturalism 101''; [http://www.action-nationale.qc.ca/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=808&Itemid=1 (See this Action Nationale article.)] # A coalition of parents drawn from different denominations (the Coalition pour la liberté en éducation) which condemn the course for different reasons: they see it as relativistic, contrary to their faith.
Many condemned the fact that the State is imposing a vision of morals and religion (or lack thereof), which has traditionally been the purview of parents.
== Court cases ==
Two legal challenges were launched against the compulsory nature of this course.
=== Public school exemption === A court case against the ERC curriculum was heard from the 11th to the 15th of May, 2009 in Quebec’s Superior Court in Drummondville. Two Catholic parents were challenging the school’s refusal of an exemption for both their first grader and their sixteen-year-old who was in last year of high school. They were arguing that the course’s contents put their children’s faith at risk by being premature, relativistic and polytheistic, and teaching ethics detached from the parents' moral framework. It was seen as a test case for Quebec parents.<ref>[http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2009/05/details-sur-le-premier-proces-ecr.html Motion text, verbatim and reports here] (in French).</ref>
The parents lost their court case and decided to bring their cause to the Supreme Court of Canada.<ref>http://news.globaltv.com/entertainment/Quebec+couple+takes+mandatory+ethics+course+Canada+court/2960927/story.html</ref>
==== Supreme Court ====
The Supreme Court granted the parents leave to appeal, but on hearing the merits determined that the appellants were unable to prove their case.
The case was heard on the 18th of May 2011 by the highest tribunal in Canada. A summary of the legal issues at stake<ref>http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/case-dossier/cms-sgd/sum-som-eng.aspx?cas=33678</ref> is listed on the Supreme Court's site. The parents' factum is to be found here.<ref>http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/factums-memoires/33678/FM010_Appelants_S.-L.-et-D.-J._%C3%A9pur%C3%A9.pdf</ref>
Apart from the original parties, 8 additional parties were granted the status of interveners (a pointer is supplied to the party's factum): # Christian Legal Fellowship;<ref>http://www.coalition-cle.org/media/memoire/FCSQ.pdf</ref> # Canadian Civil Liberties Association;<ref>http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2011/05/ecr-memoire-de-lassociation-canadienne.html</ref> # Coalition pour la liberté en éducation;<ref>http://www.coalition-cle.org/media/memoire/CLE.pdf</ref> # Evangelical Fellowship of Canada;<ref>http://www.coalition-cle.org/media/memoire/AEC-EFC.pdf</ref> # Regroupement chrétien pour le droit parental en éducation;<ref>http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2011/05/ecr-memoire-du-regroupement-chretien.html</ref> # Canadian Council of Christian Charities;<ref>http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2011/05/erc-at-supreme-court-attorney-general.html</ref> # Fédération des commissions scolaires du Québec<ref>http://www.coalition-cle.org/media/memoire/FCSQ.pdf</ref> (did not present oral arguments); # Canadian Catholic School Trustees' Association.<ref>http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2011/05/erc-at-supreme-court-of-canada-strongly.html</ref> The Evangelical Fellowship of Canada wrote [http://files.efc-canada.net/si/Education/LavalleeQA.pdf a FAQ in layman's terms] explaining what it saw as the issues at stake and how this court case differs from the Loyola one. Two court reports were published, one in English by a writer of the [http://www.catholicregister.org/canada/quebec-parents-challenge-ethics-and-religious-culture-course Catholic register], another [http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2011/05/le-programme-ecr-en-cour-supreme-du.html more detailed in French] by a parent in favour of parents being exempt of this course if they so wish.
The Supreme Court heard the case and ruled that "...[the court] cannot conclude that the appellants have been able to prove their case." <ref>http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2012/02/16/supreme-court-canada-religion-education-challenge.html</ref>
The parents were awarded the Catholics Civil Right League's yearly award<ref>http://www.ccrl.ca/index.php?id=5121</ref> for their defense of parents' free choice in education.
=== Private school exemption ===
A private Catholic high school, Loyola High School in Montreal, also launched a court challenge. Loyola High was challenging the fact that the Ministry of Education has not allowed it to teach what it deems an equivalent ethics and religion course better fitting the Catholic outlook of the school. It alleged that the Ministry had done so despite provisions in the law that would allow such an equivalent course.<ref>[http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2009/05/details-sur-le-second-proces-ecr-loyola.html French] and [http://pouruneecolelibre.blogspot.com/2009/06/loyola-explains-why-it-is-in-court-this.html English]</ref>
Loyola High won its court case and is now exempt for the ERC course and may teach its equivalent Catholic course. On the 18th of June 2010, Superior Court Justice Gerard Dugre compared the attempt of the education minister to impose a secular emphasis on Loyola High School's teaching of the course to the intolerance of the Spanish Inquisition: "The obligation imposed on Loyola to teach the ethics and religious culture course in a lay fashion assumes a totalitarian character essentially equivalent to Galileo's being ordered by the Inquisition to deny the Copernican universe," the judge wrote in [http://www.coalition-cle.org/media/Jugement-Loyola.pdf his 63-page decision]<ref>https://montrealgazette.com/life/Ruling+calls+imposition+ethics+class+totalitarian/3177787/story.html</ref><sup>, </sup>.<ref>https://montrealgazette.com/life/Court+backs+Loyola+over+ethics+course/3173865/story.html</ref>
== Surveys ==
Several polls had shown the Quebec population to be polarized around this course. While 45% opposed the course in October 2008, 72% wanted parents to be able to choose the moral and religious training their children will get at school: the new ERC course or a traditional denominational religion course.<ref>[http://matin.branchez-vous.com/nouvelles/2008/09/52_dappui_au_cours_dethique_et.html][http://www.newswire.ca/fr/releases/archive/October2008/23/c9151.html]</ref> In May 2009, the proportion of Quebecers wanting this choice had risen to 76%.<ref>[http://www.newswire.ca/fr/releases/archive/May2009/26/c7735.html]</ref>
== Jewish community response ==
On May 28, 2009, the [[Canadian Jewish News]] announced the formation of a grassroots organization to represent "a response of Orthodox Judaism to the Ethics and Religious Culture program." The organization, calling itself the Council on Jewish Education in Quebec, commended the Quebec government for championing the cause of universal friendship among human beings, and for identifying "Recognition of Others" and "Pursuit of the Common Good" as values to be taught. However, the organization contended that because Orthodox Jews are required according to Torah law to limit their study of theology to the theology of the Torah, the curriculum should consist of the [[Noahide]] Code. The "Hade'ah Vihaddibur" online Orthodox Jewish weekly newspaper reported a comparable sentiment expressed by the Israeli halakhic decisor [[Yosef Shalom Eliashiv]]. Consistent with this response, the [[Montreal Gazette]], in an op/ed published on June 6, 2009 (p. B6), noted that Quebec Jewish school curricula are exclusively loyal to the theology of the Torah.
== Sources == *[http://www.mels.gouv.qc.ca/en/contenus-communs/education/ethics-and-religious-culture-program/ Official curriculum] *[http://catholicinsight.com/online/church/education/article_877.shtml Summary of the court challenges] *[https://nationalpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1083934 Quebec's new creepy curriculum] *[http://www.sherbrookerecord.com/content/view/82415/27/ Ethics and Religion generates debate] *[http://www.samizdat.qc.ca/vc/quest_soc/pomo_catechism_pg.htm Ethics and religious culture: The New Post-Modern Catechism.]

'''Saint Grobian''' ([[Medieval Latin]], ''Sanctus Grobianus'') was a fictional [[patron saint]] of vulgar and coarse people. His name is derived from the [[Middle High German]] ''grob'' or ''grop'', meaning coarse or vulgar. The [[Old High German]] [[cognate]] is ''gerob'', ''gerop''.
The word "grobian" has thus passed into the [[English language]] as an obscure word for any crude, sloppy, or [[buffoon]]ish person.
==History== [[File:Narrenschiff (1549).jpg|right|thumb|Narrenschiff]] The satirist [[Sebastian Brant]] (1457-1521) conceived Saint Grobian as the patron saint of coarse manners in his famous poem ''[[Das Narrenschiff]]'' (1494). ''Das Narrenschiff'' describes the worship paid to this new saint.
Grobian is found later in several works of the period.
[[Friedrich Dedekind]] (1524-1598) published ''Grobianus et Grobiana: sive, de morum simplicitate, libri tres'' in 1558 at [[Cologne]]. Here Grobian is a counselor who teaches men on how to avoid bad manners, [[gluttony]], and [[drunkenness]].
Dedekind's work appeared in [[England]] in 1605 as ''The Schoole of Slovenrie: Or, Cato turnd wrong side outward'', published by one "R.F.". The "Schoole" was imagined as a place where one was instructed to use one's greasy [[finger]]s to grab at the nicest portions of any dish and snatch food belonging to fellow diners. Holding back the desire to [[urinate]], [[Flatulence|fart]], and [[vomiting|vomit]] is taught to be bad for one's health; thus, one has to indulge freely in all three activities.
The work also inspired [[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]]'s ''The Guls Horne-Booke'' (1609).
The [[Germany|German]] writer [[Melchior Meyr]] was the author of a work entitled ''Gespräche mit einem Grobian'' (1866).
Sebastian Brant's [[allegory]] was translated into English by [[Alexander Barclay]] and [[Henry Watson (poet)|Henry Watson]] as ''[[Ship of Fools (satire)|Ship of Fools]]'', both in 1509. See also [[ship of fools]].
==Sources== *Rod Evans, ''The Gilded Tongue'' (Cincinnati: Writers Digest Books, 2006), 59.
==External links== *{{en icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20060811225907/http://leehrsn.stormloader.com/dek/intro.html Gull’s Hornbook] *{{en icon}} [http://www.johnwebster.galeon.com/glossary-g.htm Glossary: Grobianism]
